articles.headline: Calorie-Counting Rule to Leave Out Movie Theaters
articles.snippet: After opposition from the movie industry, theaters were exempted from a proposed rule that would require restaurants to post calorie counts next to menu items.
articles.abstract: After opposition from the movie industry, theaters were exempted from a proposed rule that would require restaurants to post calorie counts next to menu items.
articles.lead_paragraph: Movie theaters don’t hesitate to wag a stern finger at their patrons: Shhh! Turn off your cellphone. Don’t talk during the movie.

articles.headline: College Plans You Thought Were Safe
articles.snippet: A prepaid tuition plan in Illinois that promised parents “peace of mind” for their children’s college educations is now a source of worry.
articles.abstract: A prepaid tuition plan in Illinois that promised parents “peace of mind” for their children’s college educations is now a source of worry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The predicament of state workers has drawn a great deal of attention recently, and rightly so. The health of their pension plans and their right to organize are fundamental issues.

articles.headline: Religious Radicals’ Turn to Democracy Alarms Egypt
articles.snippet: Islamic fundamentalists are embracing democracy, alarming those who believe that they are seeking to put in place strict Islamic law through ballots.
articles.abstract: Islamic fundamentalists are embracing democracy, alarming those who believe that they are seeking to put in place strict Islamic law through ballots.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAHIA, Egypt — Abboud al-Zomor — the former intelligence officer who supplied the bullets that killed President Anwar el-Sadat and is Egypt’s most notorious newly released prisoner — waxes enthusiastic about ending the violent jihad he once led.

articles.headline: Air Traffic System Update Encountered Turbulence
articles.snippet: The Federal Aviation Administration’s proposal to modernize the nation’s air traffic control system, long held up by airlines’ cost concerns, got a boost on Friday in the House.
articles.abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration’s proposal to modernize the nation’s air traffic control system, long held up by airlines’ cost concerns, got a boost on Friday in the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Imagine an air traffic system where planes would no longer have to wait in long rush-hour lines before taking off, or have to circle the skies before landing. In this world, planes would be able to fly more direct routes and land along smoother glide paths.

articles.headline: Mission Accomplished, Nonprofits Go Out of Business
articles.snippet: Some nonprofits, like one fighting malaria or another serving victims of the Nazis, are happily closing their doors as they run out of work.
articles.abstract: Some nonprofits, like one fighting malaria or another serving victims of the Nazis, are happily closing their doors as they run out of work.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few nonprofit groups have recently announced plans to wind down, not over financial problems but because their missions are nearly finished.

articles.headline: The Bank Run We Knew So Little About
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve documents show how the dire the global banking crisis was becoming as early as summer 2007.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve documents show how the dire the global banking crisis was becoming as early as summer 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN August 2007, as world financial markets were seizing up, domestic and foreign banks began lining up for cash from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

articles.headline: For Tiger Woods, a Golf Course Design Business Is in the Rough
articles.snippet: In Mexico, Dubai and North Carolina, projects designed by the golf legend have not been completed.
articles.abstract: In Mexico, Dubai and North Carolina, projects designed by the golf legend have not been completed.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN late June 2008, a week after he astonished the golf world by winning the United States Open while grimacing in pain on a torn left knee, Tiger Woods traveled to a craggy chunk of land on the Baja Peninsula in Mexico. It was a lunarlike landscape of dirt and rock, with an inactive volcano in the background. For several hours, he hobbled over the terrain, discussing with developers his vision for the golf course he would build there, while waves from the Pacific crashed onto the shoreline below. His knee, said one companion, rattled like tools in a tool box.

articles.headline: Hundreds Killed in Ivory Coast Town as Conflict Intensifies
articles.snippet: As rebels swept across Ivory Coast aiming to oust the nation’s strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, hundreds of people were killed in one town in the western part of the country last week.
articles.abstract: As rebels swept across Ivory Coast aiming to oust the nation’s strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, hundreds of people were killed in one town in the western part of the country last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — As rebels swept across Ivory Coast in a rapid advance last week to oust the nation’s strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, hundreds of people were killed in a single town, the United Nations and aid groups said Saturday, in the worst episode of violence during the four-month political crisis that has plunged the country back into civil war.

articles.headline: A Club for the Women Atop the Ladder
articles.snippet: Though most members of Belizean Grove may not be household names, they represent a rare confluence of women’s wealth and influence.
articles.abstract: Though most members of Belizean Grove may not be household names, they represent a rare confluence of women’s wealth and influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON the site of a 17th-century monastery in Cartagena, Colombia, a sort of Illuminati of the business and political worlds  gathered in February for their annual winter rites.

articles.headline: In Israel, Time for Peace Offer May Run Out
articles.snippet: The United Nations may this year vote to recognize a Palestinian state, placing Israel into a diplomatic vise.
articles.abstract: The United Nations may this year vote to recognize a Palestinian state, placing Israel into a diplomatic vise.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — With revolutionary fervor sweeping the Middle East, Israel is under mounting pressure to make a far-reaching offer to the Palestinians or face a United Nations vote welcoming the State of Palestine as a member whose territory includes all of the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.

articles.headline: An Obama Insider, Running the Race From Afar
articles.snippet: Jim Messina, previously a White House deputy chief of staff, is running the president’s re-election campaign, which will formally open its doors in Chicago this week.
articles.abstract: Jim Messina, previously a White House deputy chief of staff, is running the president’s re-election campaign, which will formally open its doors in Chicago this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For two years, Jim Messina worked 41 steps from the Oval Office, a distance he counted when he first arrived at the White House. His next assignment — in an office 700 miles from President Obama — will test whether proximity is the key to power.

articles.headline: Tipping the Odds for a Maker of Heart Implants
articles.snippet: Cardiologists paid as consultants may have smoothed the way for a little-known company to corner a market.
articles.abstract: Cardiologists paid as consultants may have smoothed the way for a little-known company to corner a market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Las Vegas is a city of few sure bets. But there are overwhelming odds on one thing — the brand of heart device that patients at a major hospital get.

articles.headline: Budget Battle to Be Followed by a Bigger Fight
articles.snippet: As Congress struggled to reach an immediate deal on federal spending to avert a government shutdown, House Republicans were completing a far-reaching budget proposal.
articles.abstract: As Congress struggled to reach an immediate deal on federal spending to avert a government shutdown, House Republicans were completing a far-reaching budget proposal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress has yet to settle its first budget fight of the year but is already about to move on to an even more consequential fiscal clash.

articles.headline: BP Seeks to Resume Drilling in Gulf of Mexico
articles.snippet: BP is seeking permission to keep drilling at 10 existing deepwater wells in the gulf in exchange for adhering to stricter safety rules.
articles.abstract: BP is seeking permission to keep drilling at 10 existing deepwater wells in the gulf in exchange for adhering to stricter safety rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — BP has asked United States regulators for permission to resume drilling in the Gulf of Mexico, two company officials said on Sunday, creating a delicate situation for the Obama administration as it seeks to balance safety concerns with a desire to increase domestic oil production.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and John M. Broder

articles.headline: Rebel Leadership in Libya Shows Strain
articles.snippet: As stalemate threatens their fight with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, rebels are suffering from infighting.
articles.abstract: As stalemate threatens their fight with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, rebels are suffering from infighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — With the rebels’ battlefield fortunes sagging, the three men in charge of the Libyan opposition forces were summoned late last week by the ad-hoc leadership of their movement to a series of meetings here in the rebel capital.

articles.headline: U.S. Shifts to Seek Removal of Yemen’s Leader, an Ally
articles.snippet: The United States, which long supported Yemen’s president, even in the face of recent protests, has shifted positions.
articles.abstract: The United States, which long supported Yemen’s president, even in the face of recent protests, has shifted positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — The United States, which long supported Yemen’s president, even in the face of recent widespread protests, has now quietly shifted positions and has concluded that he is unlikely to bring about the required reforms and must be eased out of office, according to American and Yemeni officials.
articles.byline: By Laura Kasinof and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: No Longer Shackled by AOL
articles.snippet: Nimble businesses, like Engadget years ago and The Huffington Post now, drew AOL’s attention, but they risk becoming one more cog in the machine.
articles.abstract: Nimble businesses, like Engadget years ago and The Huffington Post now, drew AOL’s attention, but they risk becoming one more cog in the machine.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2005, Jim Bankoff was working at AOL as executive vice president in charge of products and programming. He decided that AOL needed to move aggressively into news if the business, then still a portal clinging to dial-up customers, was to survive the shift to broadband and the onslaught of new digital sites.

articles.headline: For Illumination Entertainment, Animation Meets Economic Reality
articles.snippet: Christopher Meledandri is trying to prove that strict cost controls and hit animated films are not mutually exclusive.
articles.abstract: Christopher Meledandri is trying to prove that strict cost controls and hit animated films are not mutually exclusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Hollywood’s cartoon kings typically work in splendorous surroundings. Jeffrey Katzenberg runs DreamWorks Animation from a Mediterranean-style campus replete with olive trees and fountains. At Pixar’s glistening complex, John Lasseter has an Olympic-size swimming pool.

articles.headline: A Wiki Takes Aim at Obama
articles.snippet: A group with ties to Karl Rove has a Web site to collect freedom of information requests that scrutinize Obama.
articles.abstract: A group with ties to Karl Rove has a Web site to collect freedom of information requests that scrutinize Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven J. Law, the president of Crossroads GPS, a well-financed conservative political group with ties to Karl Rove, had a revelation a few months ago while watching television news.

articles.headline: Hole in Southwest Jet Attributed to Cracks
articles.snippet: The fatigue cracks that caused the hole would not have been apparent on a visual inspection, an official said, while cracks were found on two more jets.
articles.abstract: The fatigue cracks that caused the hole would not have been apparent on a visual inspection, an official said, while cracks were found on two more jets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The five-foot hole that ripped open midflight Friday in the roof of a Southwest Airlines jet and terrified passengers on their way to Sacramento from Phoenix was caused by fatigue cracks in the aluminum underskin of the lap joints, the National Transportation Safety Board said Sunday.
articles.byline: By Joseph Berger and Duff Wilson

articles.headline: At China’s New Museum, History Toes Party Line
articles.snippet: The National Museum of China showcases the Communist Party’s efforts to control the narrative of history.
articles.abstract: The National Museum of China showcases the Communist Party’s efforts to control the narrative of history.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — At the elaborately renovated National Museum of China in Tiananmen Square, visitors interested in the recent history of the world’s fastest rising power can gaze at the cowboy hat that Deng Xiaoping once wore when he visited the United States, or admire the bullhorn that President Hu Jintao used to exhort people to overcome hardship after the Sichuan earthquake in 2008.

articles.headline: Ruling Spurs Effort to Form Digital Public Library
articles.snippet: A judge’s derailment of Google’s plan to build a digital library and bookstore was seen by some scholars and librarians as a chance to pursue a better universal public library.
articles.abstract: A judge’s derailment of Google’s plan to build a digital library and bookstore was seen by some scholars and librarians as a chance to pursue a better universal public library.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is the tantalizing dream of a universal library dead?

articles.headline: Dark Past in Balkan War Intrudes on New Life
articles.snippet: Azra Basic, arrested in Kentucky, could stand trial in Bosnia and Herzegovina on charges of war crimes.
articles.abstract: Azra Basic, arrested in Kentucky, could stand trial in Bosnia and Herzegovina on charges of war crimes.
articles.lead_paragraph: STANTON, Ky. — Nearly two decades after fleeing her native Croatia, the squat, hardworking woman known as Issabell Basic lived a quiet life in this small town, firing up her Jeep Cherokee each day for the 25-minute commute to her job making Hot Pockets.

articles.headline: A Tea Party Star Stirs Iowans, and She Isn’t Palin
articles.snippet: Should Michele Bachmann run for president, she could have a big impact on the G.O.P. field.
articles.abstract: Should Michele Bachmann run for president, she could have a big impact on the G.O.P. field.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa — Sarah Palin, the reigning heroine of many social conservatives, has given few signals that she will make a presidential bid. Mike Huckabee, who won the Iowa caucuses in 2008 on the strength of his appeal to evangelicals and other constituencies, has mostly offered reasons for not joining the race.

articles.headline: F.A.A. to Order Airlines to Inspect 737s for Cracks
articles.snippet: The directive came after a five-foot hole ripped through the roof of a Southwest Airlines jet on Friday during a flight.
articles.abstract: The directive came after a five-foot hole ripped through the roof of a Southwest Airlines jet on Friday during a flight.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration announced on Monday that it would require extensive inspections of some older-model Boeing 737s for cracks in the planes’ fragile skin that can be caused by pressurization and depressurization of the cabin over tens of thousands of takeoffs and landings.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Christopher Drew
